title: Visa Program's End Risks Project Funding
text:
The program's demise after almost 30 years would be a blow to the real-estate industry, which has come to rely on green-card applicants as a cheap source of funding. Developers of projects such as Brooklyn's Pacific Park and Steiner Studios relied on EB-5 funding to complete their visions. It isn't known whether existing investors could receive their green cards if the program expires.

Sens. Chuck Grassley (R., Iowa) and Patrick Leahy (D., Vt.) have made a proposal that would more tightly regulate which foreign investors and investment projects could qualify under EB-5. The bill would include more stringent reporting requirements on the progress those investments are making.

They proposed a five-year extension of regional centers, which are set to expire at the end of the month and allow U.S. businesses to pool money from many EB-5 investors. The centers have made it possible to fund big real-estate projects. Mr. Grassley warned colleagues that he would prefer to see the program die rather than be reauthorized without changes.

Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D., N.Y.) opposes the bipartisan bill, as do many in the real-estate and EB-5 industries. Industry representatives say they will agree to the proposed measures only if lawmakers make it easier for developers to raise money.

Messrs. Grassley and Leahy have long pushed to change the program, which they say is prone to fraud and which they believe allowed easy-to-get foreign capital to flow to urban areas rather than to more rural areas. The Securities and Exchange Commission opened a number of investigations into EB-5 projects for violating U.S. laws.

Some property developers and regional centers support the Grassley-Leahy bill. They want to avoid the risk of the program expiring, and the long reauthorization period would allow them to at least manage the money of existing EB-5 investors for many more years.

Other developers say the program has been essentially unusable since a federal rule in 2019 raised the minimum investment amount to $900,000 from $500,000 and took away the ability of states to gerrymander designated high-unemployment areas to make favored real-estate projects eligible.

On Thursday, three weeks shy of the program's expiration, Sens. Leahy and Schumer held a call with industry representatives where the groups tentatively agreed to try to find a compromise, according to two people who participated.

Some industry groups proposed shortening the extension from five years to one year to give them an earlier chance to renegotiate the program's rules.
